Row.Text: EXPLORER READY
COLONY SHIP ARRIVES
A NATION IS BORN
WORLD WAR I
WORLD WAR II
ADDITIONAL COLONISTS
An adventurous explorer has departed the British colony of New South Wales to uncover the mysteries of the Australian continent.
We have recruited a ship of hardy souls to start your new colony. We have high hopes for this band: not all of them are convicts.

Now that many generations have lived and died as native Australians, our people want to form our separate states into a united country. It is time for Australia to federate, forming a new nation independent from Britain.
A great war afflicts the continent of Europe and our mother country of Britain has been thrown into that fray. We will send troops to lend our support.

Another world war has broken out and this time even our homeland of Australia is at risk. As our prime minister John Curtin has reminded us: “The flame of freedom lit in this land by our first settlers, and kept aglow by the generations which followed, is not extinguishable by any enemy.”
Your civic progress has been noticed back in England. More colonists have just arrived wishing to make your colony their new home.
Use this explorer for the next four turns to find the best place for a new settlement.
A free Settler will appear at the start of next turn in the coastal tile closest to your explorer.
Once you complete the Federation Civic you will be able to upgrade to the strongest governmental system, State Government.

You may now initiate the AIF project in any of your cities. Each such contribution you make to the war effort will enhance your state’s standing in our nation, earning you +10 [ICON_Gold] Gold per turn.
Completing the AIF project is even more critical at this time and will reward you with +20 [ICON_Gold] Gold per turn.
A free Settler has appeared in your capital. From this point forward, new cities must be built within 10 tiles of one of your existing cities.
Your {1_UnitName} has suffered {2_Damage} damage.
Your {1_UnitName} has been killed.
Your {1_UnitName} has permanently lost 1 [ICON_Movement] Movement.
You lose {1_Amount} [ICON_Gold] Gold.
Your {1_UnitName} has returned to the nearest city of {2_CityName}.
Your nearby {1_Improvement} has been pillaged.
Your {1_UnitName} has lost {2_Movement} movement points for this turn.
Your {1_UnitName} will not be able to move this turn.
Knowledge of some of the terrain near {1_UnitName} has been lost.
A {1_UnitName} has arrived in the closest city of {2_CityName}.
A {1_UnitName} has arrived next to your {2_UnitName}.
Unexplored territory near your {1_UnitName} has been revealed.
Your {1_UnitName} has permanently gained +1 [ICON_Movement] Movement.
Your {1_UnitName} has been completely healed.
Your {1_UnitName} has had {2_HitPoints} points of damage healed.
Your nearby city of {1_CityName} has gained 1 Population.
You gain {1_Amount} [ICON_Gold] Gold.
You receive a Eureka for the technology {1_TechName}.
Your receive an Inspiration for the civic {1_CivicName}.
Caught in Rip Current
Brushed Against Box Jellyfish
Collected a Cone Shell
Delayed by Perilous Fog
Resupplied by Aboriginal Fishermen
Rock Hoppers For Hire
Bountiful Waters Located
Woefully Underestimated Water Needs
Stampeding Camels
Stepped on Death Adder
Delayed by Incessant Dust Storm
Oasis Spotted
Found Unguarded Dingo Litter
Waylaid by Bushrangers
Caught in Bushfire
Harassed by Dingoes
Ate the Wrong Berries
Resupplied by Squatters
Swagmen For Hire
Rockslide!
Exceptionally Freezing Nights
Supplies Fell Into Gorge
Fruitless Passage
Fossickers For Hire
Discovered Mountain Spring
Altercation With Red Kangaroo
Continuing Drought Conditions
Spinifex Infection
Complete Loss of Direction
Stockmen For Hire
Led to Water by Galah Flock
Malarial Woes
Starved Out By Plague Locusts
Washed Away in Flash Flood
Bogged Down in Mudflats
Caught Yabbies In Stream
Consumed By Saltwater Crocodile
Horrid Infested Wounds
Bitten by Funnel Web Spider
Ate the Wrong Fish
Lost in the Swamp
Frightful Bunyip Rumors
Infested With Threadworms
Drank Too Much Water Too Quickly
Averted a Near Mutiny
Recuperated at Billabong
Peaceful Recuperation
Everything Here Is Poison
Startled a Cassowary
Afflicted With Dengue Fever
Plagued by Stinging Ant Swarm
Uncovered Scientific Mystery
Agitated Eastern Brown Snake
Burnt Firewood From Gum Tree
Angered Territorial Emu
Spurious Drop Bear Rumors
Discovered Emu Egg Clutch
Inauspicious Fall
Stricken By Scurvy
Conflicted Direction
Forgot to Tether Horses
Discovered a Shortcut
Resupplied by Aboriginal Clan
Followed Dingo Trail
Dispute With Rival Explorers
Discovered Inaccuracies In Maps
Treasure!
Aboriginal Guides For Hire
Inadvertently Offended Aboriginals
Accidentally Started Bushfire
Aboriginal Migration
Fruitless Discourse With Aboriginals
What began as a refreshing dip in the ocean ended in tragedy.
Such a fragile thing, full of liquid pain.
A beautiful exterior conceals a tiny, venomous harpoon.
It rolled in from the sea, thicker than cannon smoke.
They knew local waters and caught local fish. We did neither.
How do they fish from coastal rocks without slipping? A mystery!
It was a wonderful find. Enough to support a settlement.
The horses were the first to die, delirious from thirst.
Abandoned by early colonists, they have since gone feral.
It all blends together in that sun-blasted terrain. Even snakes.
It got into everything. Days later we still shed it in our wake.
We found an island of life in that blasted wasteland.
You must understand. It was necessary for our survival.
They took food but left us water. They were thieves, not killers.
It burned hotter than a foundry. Brows singed and skin seared.
They hounded us for days, eventually killing a stray pack animal.
The pain ran through our guts like hot coals.
They were making a new life for themselves, out in the bush.
Itinerant farmers sought steady work, depending on the season.
It was our misfortune to have camped in its path.
Meager blankets couldn't stop a chill wind from the mountains.
In hindsight, we should have stored them further from the edge.
What seemed a promising shortcut led to a day of wasted effort.
Many sought goldfields far and wide. Few found real fortunes.
A sheltered spring provided us with all the water we could carry.
In our defense, we sought to learn what it carried in its pouch.
Greedy plants would have us die of thirst before they did.
The leaf tips broke off in our flesh as we brushed against them.
In endlessly similar terrain, it was quite easy to lose our way.
It was lonely and hard work, but they didn't mind the conditions.
We marched to where they settled. Beautiful birds. A bit gamey.
There were enough mosquitos in the air to darken the sky.
They ravaged the landscape of anything that could sustain us.
If unable to reach high ground, one could quite simply vanish.
Some boots and stockings were lost to the muck.
They are edible when boiled, with the exception of their shells.
There was no sound or scream. Just a ripple on the water.
Those blasted bluebottles were most certainly the culprits.
The smaller the creature, the more potent its poison. Generally.
Not all fish are for eating. Especially not that one.
The terrain seems to shift through the day. Trick of the light?
There is no question that a bush spirit stalked us in that swamp.
Even the Outback's freshest water carries intestinal dangers.
After a being without for so long, thirst leads to poor choices.
They refused to depart the oasis. It nearly came to blows.
The lonely waterhole lifted our spirits.
A lovely day. Would that it could balance out all the others.
Every insect, animal, flower, root, or vine might have killed us.
To think, when it first leapt and kicked out its feet we laughed.
The fever lasted for some time before a wound bore fate's seal.
We had the singular misfortune of bedding down atop ant hills.
There are wonders to be found in this strange wood.
It revealed its malefic nature when it struck for no good reason.
We didn't foresee the explosion. Some thought it a cannon attack.
Its ferocious pecking caught us offguard.
We never encountered a carnivorous koala. We were the lucky ones.
When eaten raw, the yolk had the consistency of bush oysters.
If need be you could shoot a hobbled mount. Not so with a person.
Skin would slough off the roof of one's mouth. Quite unpleasant.
Harsh conditions and frayed tempers oft lead to squabbling.
A simple mistake in town. Less so in the Outback.
A seemingly unremarkable path would show promise, on occasion.
Lucky for us, not everywhere in the bush is devoid of human life.
The dingoes traveled to water and prey. Best to follow the locals.
Many were keen to claim findings for themselves.
Perhaps they were correct. Perspective is strange in the Outback.
A shame it was found on the corpse of a failed explorer.
We were able to split our party to cover more ground.
Much later, we understood it to be a grave insult to the clan.
At the time, we had no idea how far it would travel. All too far.
Poor conditions led them to seek their fortunes elsewhere.
It seems their previous encounters with outsiders were negative.
Swept out to sea, presumed drowned.
Set foot on mating stingers. Amputation unsuccessful.
Held cone shell to ear. Didn't hear the ocean.
Visibility nonexistent. No progress.
Traded for fresh food and water.
Agreeable sorts, eager for work.
It's a veritable cornucopia. Location recorded.
To survive, we rely on the water we make.
Trampled. Blinded by dromedary spittle. Morale low.
Bitten on the calf. Lungs closed soon after.
Visibility nonexistent. Spittle muddy. No progress.
Welcome relief in sight. Location recorded.
Victuals replenished. Morale low.
Lost teeth in initial fisticuffs. Victuals also lost.
Could not discern remains amongst the ash. Pressing on.
Endless howling. Four nights without sleep. Morale low.
Dehydrated. Demoralized. Too weak to travel.
Fed and resupplied. Morale high.
Provided map to nearest settlement.
Medical supplies lost. Injuries remain, poorly treated.
Frostbite. Must press on before we are all afflicted.
Recovery attempt failed. Hungry, wounded, demoralized.
Pass was a dead end. Returned to previous campsite.
Directed fossickers to nearest colonial mining office.
Sheltered and resupplied. Good foraging. Morale high.
Repeated kicks led to organ damage, followed by death.
Land parched. Expedition also parched. Onward.
Impossible to avoid spinifex clumps in this terrain.
Crossed yesterday's path twice before noon. Morale low.
Nearest outback station will soon have more stockmen.
Waterskins and bellies filled to bursting. Morale high.
Endless fever. Convalescence impracticable. Morale low.
Foraging ineffectual. Belts tightened. Morale low.
Swept out of camp in the night, presumed dead.
No notable progress. Covered in flies. Morale low.
Found crustaceans! Victuals replenished. Morale high.
Departed when we thought it sated. Misjudged, once.
The afflicted fled screaming into marsh. Presumed dead.
What horrors this inhospitable land contains!
A messy death followed complete paralysis.
Hours of hard travel. Found camp. Ours, from yesterday.
Bunyip claims is clear attempt to shirk. No progress.
Itching led to infection. Can't sleep or remain seated.
Expected to recover from water sickness. No progress.
Prudence suggests we extend our period of recuperation.
Enjoyable ablutions. Morale high.
Victuals replenished. Waterskins bulging. Morale high.
Another dead for unknown reason from unfamiliar source.
Throat cut by bird with razor claws. Death was quick.
It's dengue. We all know how this ends. Morale low.
Bedrolls unusable. Spent day smoking out the ants.
Took copious notes. Naming rights shall be ours!
Reiterated the dangers of cornering snakes.
Horses unnerved. Burns salved. Eyebrows singed.
Eye lost. Orbit infected. Emu haunch offered to victim.
Lost a day to abject twaddle. Fools surround me.
Victuals replenished. Morale high.
Severe injury due to vagaries of terrain.
In desperate need of quality victuals.
It came to blows, some of them serious. Morale low.
Emphasized, with vehemence, the necessity of tethering.
Found a hidden trail to expedite tomorrow's journey.
Traded for fresh food and water. Ever onward.
Found billabong, chased off dingoes, replenished water.
Eventually reached agreement for shared naming rights.
Some additional exploration needed. Location noted.
Promise of reward has excited our numbers. Morale high.
What luck! We have now doubled our fortunes.
Hastily departed area to avoid further antagonization.
Campfire embers began the blaze. Fled for our lives.
Directed clan to nearest settlement. Onward.
Trade refused, despite assurances. Departed soon after.
